div.p: The 〈◊〉 tragedy of Herod and Antipater: with the death of fair Marriam.
According to Josephus, the learned and famous Jew.
As it hath been, of late, divers tims publicly acted (With great applause) at the red bull, by the company of his majesty's revels.

Written by
Gervase Markham
William Simpson.gentlemen.

lg.l: Readers: whose hearts have sparkled with desire
To be inflamed with Promethian fire,
Fetched from Parnassus shrine (The muse's mount)
To you I write, that make so dear account
E'en of arts merest shadows; you contemn
The drossy substance, highly prized by men.
Of earthy breeding; who can never glean
The least content from a trile tragical scene
Of high and noble nature; nor care they
To hear, or understand; but see a play:
For tragedy or history, you shall
Never find these at any stationer's stall
Bestow one sixpence: but, for bald discourses
Of comic ribaldry, they'll draw their purses.
Hence is the cause, that storeys (Like to this)
Shall lie in dark obscurity, and miss
The printers press, t'adorn and set them forth
In the true glories of their native worth;
When carrion-comedies (Not worth an hair)
Must be set out with excellent and rare
Strange undeserving titles: but, let these
Merit such liking as their readers please.
Here I have sent and printed to your view
A story; which I dare be bold is 〈◊〉
Now newly writ, and truly worthy
Gathered from learned Josephus 〈…〉
Is, that it may your kind 〈…〉
I then shall count my 〈…〉
So happily bestowed 〈…〉
For your Content● 〈…〉
Time's eldest daughter (Truth) presents our play;
And, from forgotten monuments of clay,
Calls up th'heroic spirits of old times,
Famed then as well for virtues as black crimes;
And with her own tongue, and own phrase, to tell
The actions they have done; or ill, or well.
Josephus th'ancient writer, with a pen
Lent by the Muses, gives new life to men;
Who breathed such tragic accents forth toth' ear
Of hebrew armies, which you now shall hear;
Please you to sit attentive: wit hath run
In a zodaicall circle, like the sun,
Through all invention; which is grown so poor
She can show naught, but what has been before:
Yet reverend history, which upon the stage
Hath oft been heard speak; hopes, even for her age,
Your strong hands will support her; she must live
Now by no heat, but what your beams do give:
To gain which (Though her scenes seem grave and high)
She here and there with a loose wing doth fly;
Striving to make you merry: no other bays
She reaches at, but this; your loves, your praise.

div.head: The true tragedy of Herod and Antipater.
Actus 1. Scoena 1.
div.stage: Enter at one door Alexandra in her petticoat; at another, Aristobulus the high priest in his waistcoat or shirt, both amazedly.

sp.speaker: Qu. Alexandra.
sp.l: O my thrice princely son; thou hast forgotten
That time's our master, and we can dispose
But merely of the instant.

sp.speaker: Eld. Arist.
sp.l: Madam true:
Nor have I lost a moment; yet I know,
No diligence appears to those, whose hearts
Do both desire and wait.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Enough, enough;
Come let's away, my heart is winged with haste
That outflies thought or motion; Egypt (Sweet)
Hath safety in it, not Jerusalem.

sp.speaker: Eld. Arist.
sp.l: I do confess it; yet this dangerous way
Of our escape, hath many fears about it.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: There's pregnant reason for it, and our lives
are marks that Herod shoots at: who but sees
The woeful state of sad Jerusalem,
And how this tyrant (Like an angry boar)
Roots up the goodly pines should cover him?
Hath he not slain Antigonus, destroyed
Thy father and thy grandsire: (Oh my lords,
My dear loved lords, my father and my husband;)
Worthy Hircanus, noble Alexander;
And at this instant lies he not in wait
For our destructions? Beldame that I am
To prate at such a season; (Holy sweet)
Come let's away, our flight is so secure,
No art can undermine it; any pause
Opens our graves before us: fly, oh fly.

sp.speaker: Eld. Arist.
sp.l: I do attend your highness.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Hark, I hear
The steps of some pursues us; prithee come,
Let Egypt and not Juda be our tomb.

div.stage: Enter at one door Antipater at another Animis, with a band of soldiers.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: Is this the diligence your duty shows,
To run this slothful pace? By all I love,
You're worthy of blame in high terms.

sp.speaker: Anim.
sp.l: Princely Antipater

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You're too improvident, and this neglect
Will draw your life in hazard; understand,
They're lions and not lambs you cope withal:
The mother-queen is subtile, and her son
Of high and noble spirit; should they scape,
You fix a ram to batter down the life
Both of the King and kingdom.

sp.speaker: Ani.
sp.l: Gracious sir,
Fear not my care; for nothing you can wish
Is able to outstrip my diligence.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: I but awake the duty which you owe
Unto your King and country; when that moves,
Children are strangers, fathers are unknown,
And where our prince's health is questioned,
the lives we either borrow or do lend
Must be forgotten and made ridiculous:
You understand me, go, dispatch, away.

sp.speaker: Ani.
sp.l: With faith great as your longings.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So, why so;
Thus have I started bravely, and maintained
My race with full speed to ambition;
Much of my way is smoothed by the deaths
Of proud Antigonus and Alexander,
But chiefly of Hircanus, till he went
My torch could never kindle; could I now
But damp the high priest Aristobulus,
(As there's much water towards) and in it
Drown his old politic mother, half my way
Lies as my thoughts would wish it; and howe'er
By birth I am a bastard, yet my wit
Shall bear me 'bove the trueborn; for 'tis found,
Power makes all things lawful, all things sound.

div.stage: Cornets: and, enter Herod, Marriam, Kiparim, Alexander, Aristobulus, Salumith, Pheroas, Joseph and attendants.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Who sits on the tribunal, sits on thorn,
And dangers do surround him; for at it
Envy stands ever gazing, and with darts
Headed with lightning strikes unto the heart
Of every noble action: what can Kings
Do, that the rude not censure and pervert
To vild interpretations? Nay, although
Justice and mercy guard them; though men's faults
Are grown so odious, that even cruelty
Is a commended goodness, mere distrust
A reasonable virtue; secrecy,
Important and most needful; and suspect,
A worthy truth, which needs no witnesses:
Yet, in this case, (Where men cannot err twice)
What shall we do, that shall scape infamy?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fine dissimulation!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: O 'tis a hell to think on, that howe'er
our natures are inclined to pity, yet
Our actions must be cruel (Or so thought)
To guard our lives from danger; wicked men
With their sins so transform us. Oh my love,
This unto thee I speak, whose tender heart
I know hath bitter thoughts, when it records
Thy fathers and thy grandfathers mishaps:
'Tis true, I caused them die; but (Gentle sweet)
Necessity, thy safety, mine, nay all the lands,
Were my most just assistants; and the act
Was noble, howe'er blamed of cruelty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My dearest lord, do not mistake my temper,
My grandfather, and father, when they fell,
However nature taught mine eyes to weep,
Yet in my love to you I buried them;
They were rich jewels once, but, set by you,
They have nor price, nor lustre; 'tis mine eye
That pities them, my heart doth honour you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O you're a goodness passed equality,
And all the blessed times which are to come
Shall with more admiration than belief
Receive th'incredible, but undoubted truth,
Of your rare mildness, faith and temperance.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: It shall indeed; and be this kiss a seal
Of our perpetual love-knot; yet (My Queen)
There are new treason's hatching, which (Believe't)
Will stretch thy patience higher: Joseph, read
That strange and cunning letter.

stage.p: I write short Alexandra, for fear of interception; that Herod's cruelty extendeth to the death of thy husband, and imprisonment of thyself, I lament: aid I cannot send thee; but if by flight thou canst escape, Egypt shall receive thee: I am glad thy son Aristobulus is high priest, let him accompany thy journey: if I should deal for thee by force, I raise two mighty enemies, Rome and Juda; thou art wise, fare as myself: thine Cleopatra, Q. of Egypt.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: These are miraculous treasons.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Subtle plots.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Strange intertwining mischiefs,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Say not so,
Give them a gentler title; nothings read
That doth accuse my mother or my brother.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: Indeed 'tis but an invitation
Of others love, not their confederacy.

sp.speaker: Y. Ari.
sp.l: Th' Egyptian Queen persuades, but their consent
Is not conceived here.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Dear wife and sons,
Love hath a blindfold judgement; would their hearts
Were harmless as your wishes; but here comes
The man will reconcile us: captain, speak,
Where's Alexandra? Where's Aristobulus?

div.stage: Enter Animis with soldiers, bringing two trunks.

sp.speaker: Ani.
sp.l: Sir, they are fled.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Fled! do not speak it; better thou hadst sunk
To hell, then bring that mischief.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: O the devil!
This was your hackney pace

sp.speaker: Ani.
sp.l: By all that's true,
I have not slacked a minute; they were gone
Ere I had my commission, and so fast,
My speed could not outstrip them; yet I took
This luggage and their servants, whence (No doubt)
Your majesty may gather new instructions.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Whence I may gather my despair and grief;
Villain, thou hast betrayed me; in their loss,
I'm lost to fate an danger: silly snail;
Could Sloth have crept so slowly? Why, thy way
Was smooth as glass, and thou mightst have surprised
Them easier then to speak it. O you gods,
What plummets hang at vassals heels; and how
Doth sleep and dulness cease them! But I vow,
Thy life shall pay thy forfeit.

sp.speaker: Ani.
sp.l: Gracious sir:

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Talkest thou of grace; and in this act hast lost,
All things that's like, or near it? Did not scorn
Hold me, my hand should kill thee.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: Good sir, think —

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: That you're too rude to offer thus to thrust
Betwixt me and my resolution.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: Not a word;
'Tis death t'outface this lightning.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Lost, and fled, and gone, and all my hope
Turned topsy turvy downward? Joseph, hark.

div.stage: Herod whispers with Joseph, and beckons all the rest unto them, but Marriam, and Antipater.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Blessed be the god of Juda, which hath brought
My royal mother, and my brother safe,
Out of the hands of sad captivity.
O, I will offer sacrifice each day,
And make that hour a sabbath, which doth bring
Them safe from threatening danger.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: Madam, amen;
With that prayer I'll join ever, and invoke
Prosperity to guard them; — but (In heart)
Wish that damnation, like a thunderbolt,
Would beat them into cinders.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis resolved,
Force shall compel what virtuously I would
Have sought from mild entreaty; for those trunks,
Go throw them into Silo, let that lake
Devour them and their treasures.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Not so good,
You may, by that means, blindfold cast away
What you would after purchase with your blood;
But cannot then recall it: sir, conceive;
There may be complots, letters, stratagems,
And things we cannot dream of.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: Nay, perhaps
Some new negotiations.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Pa●er tongues,
That may discover strange dissemblers.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: True,
You have prevailed, break up those rotten tombs,
Let's see what ghosts they harbour. Ha, what's this?

div.stage: Here they break open the trunks, and find Alexandra, and Aristobulus the elder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O me, my mother and my brother! Eyes
Drop out and see not their destruction.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: Unhappy chance.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Unfortunate young man.

sp.speaker: Y. Arist.
sp.l: 'Tis fate not to be shunned.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: Woe the time.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What's here: the high priest like a juggler?
Are these his holy garments; this his robe,
His breastplate and his ephod, his rich coat,
His mitre and his girdle? Can it be,
That this was once Queen of Jerusalem?
O you immortal gods, to what disguise
Will treachery transform us!

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Rather think,
How sharp a plague is tyranny: oh King,
Remember 'tis the fiercest beast, of all
That are accounted savage; yet delights
In flattery, which is the worst of them
That are tame and domestic: with these fiends
My life can find no pleasure; do not then
Blame me to seek my freedom.

sp.speaker: Eld. Arist.
sp.l: Mighty sir,
If life be th'only jewel heaven can lend,
And that in the creation was not made
A thing of equal purchase; how can we
Offend, that but preserve it? You may say,
It hath deceived us; yet sir, I will think
Howe'er it finish here, 'tis but a stroke
To draw it forth unto eternity.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis a good resolution; for (Believe't)
Your days on earth are finished; treacherous plots
Like these, shall not o'er take me.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: But your tyranny
Shall outrun all example: sir, despair
Arms me with truth and boldness; I dare now
Tell you, of Kings, you are the wickedest;
And I, that in the ruins of my blood,
Read your destroying nature, and collect
Into a short brief many tragedies,
Acted upon our family; what hope
Is left, that can assist us?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You are plain.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Truth hath no need of figures: was't not you
That did betray Hircanus in his flight
To the Arabian monarch; and when laid
In harmless sleep then slew him? Did not you
Hire the bloody Cassius to cut off
My father's head, (The loved Antigonus?)
Have you not killed my husband, trod my sons
Into the mire, that you might safely walk
Over their heads unto ambition?
And can you hope, that we have any hope
In you, but desolation?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Your despair
Turn temperance into folly; charity
Would more become the dying.

sp.speaker: E. Arist.
sp.l: 'Tis confessed;
Nor is it lost in this sad argument:
We know our lives are forfeit, take them sir;
To die, is the first contract that was made
Twixt mankind and the world; 'tis a debt,
For which there's no forgiveness, th'only cause
For which we were created; and, indeed,
To die's man's nature, not his punishment;
What folly then would shun it? Boldly sir,
Use what your power hath conquered.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: So I will;
Your own lips are your judges; and these hands,
Armed with these two stilettoes at one blow,
Shall thus drive all fears from me; but unite
sp.stage: Offers to stab, let's the poniard fall, and embraces Ari. and Alex.
sp.l: Two friends in mine embraces; happy ones,
Exceeding happy ones; let not your fears
Draw to your eyes false figures, or make me
Appear that which I am not: come, I love you,
Dear I love you; all that I have done
Constraint, and not my nature perfitted:
Be henceforth free for ever; Egypt, nor
The world shall safelier guard you; as you stand
Thus shall you still support me; holiness
sp.stage: Places Arist. on his right hand, and Q. Alex. on his left.
sp.l: Upon my right hand; mother you shall sit
Ever upon my left hand; both shall be
Mine armour, counsel, and prosperity.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: This grace is past example; Herod's a god.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis but their first step to felicity:
Antipater, your ear.

div.stage: Herod whispers with Antipater, Antipater with Y. Alexander, and prince Aristobulus.

sp.speaker: Y. Alex.
sp.l: Mother, the King is gracious.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Past belief,
Nor shall the memory lose me; this not feigned,
I'll fix my prayers upon him.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: You shall do
Wrong to your royal nature to suspect him.

sp.speaker: E. Arist.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis true;
I hold his word a rock to build upon.

sp.speaker: P. Arist.
sp.l: The sport is excellent, the wager firm,
My person shall maintain it.

sp.speaker: Y. Alex.
sp.l: So shall mine.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: And if I shrink, make me a weathercock.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: How soon a foul day's cleared: now to make
Your happiness more constant; brother, know,
The temple of King Salomon which I
The other day defaced and threw down
Low as the earth it stood on; once again
I will erect with double excellence.
Joseph, my brother, to your noble charge
I give that holy building; see it framed
To th'height of art and wonder; spare no gold,
Jewels, nor rich embosture; I have mines,
And all shall be exhausted; that the world
May boast, King Herod outwent Salomon.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Sir, you've engaged me where my heart desired;
Doubt not my diligence.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis known too well:
How now, what news centurion? How stands fate
Between Augustus and Mark Anthony?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.l: O royal sir, deadly unfortunate;
For, never was so sad a day before
sp.stage: Antip. E. Arist. Y. Ari. P. Alex. whisper.
sp.l: Seen to o'ercover Egypt: to be brief
Augustus hath the conquest; Anthony
Lies buried in the blood his warlike hand
Struck from his royal bosom; the sad Queen
o'ertakes him with like fury, and now both
Are turned to dust and ashes.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Thou hast spoke
Much sorrow in a few words.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.l: But hold still
Far greater to unburden: soon as chance
Had made Augustus happy, and o'erthrown
Fair Cleopatra, and her Anthony;
He views his spoils, and amongst them finds the aid
Y'ad sent to interpose him: now he frowns,
Bends his enraged forehead, and protests,
That Juda and Jerusalem shall curse
They ever heard the name of Anthony:
And this he spoke with such an emphasis,
As shook my heart within me; yet gave wings
Unto my faith to tell you.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Sir, no more,
Thou'st split me with thy thunder; I have made
Rome and the world my mortal enemies;
Yet virtue did transport me; but that guard
Is no guard now: tell me, centurion,
Where did you leave Augustus?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.l: Sir, in Rhodes.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis a fair easy journey, I'm resolved;
Nor shall persuasion change me; hence I'll go,
And as a hermit throw at Caesar's feet
My crown and person; if he pity them,
My peace is made; if otherwise,
My fault flies not beyond me.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: O my son,
This is a desperate hazard.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Nay 'tis more;
A tempting of your fortune.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Be content,
Mother and sister, nothing alters me;
Nor do they love me, that would draw my will
To any other compass: Joseph, to you
I leave the realm's protection, and the care
Or building up the temple: nay, no tears,
They prophesy my death, which do but show
A low dejected countenance; if I have
Power in your hearts, this day I challenge you
To give them unto pastime, that the world
May see, we dread not fortune.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: 'Tis resolved;
And I'll be first to show obedience.
Sir, 'twixt my princely brothers and myself,
I've made a match of swimming, if you please
But to allow the contract.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: How is't made?

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: That I and th'high priest Aristobulus,
Will swim more swift, more comely, and more ways,
Then can my princely brothers.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Are all agreed?

sp.speaker: Eld. Arist.
sp.l: All, if your majesty consent thereto.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: For those young men it skills not; but sir, you,
I'm curious of your danger.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There's no fear.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: 'Tis a brave recreation.

sp.speaker: Y. Arist.
sp.l: A fit skill
For princes to delight in.

sp.speaker: Eld. Arist.
sp.l: Gracious sir,
Let me consort my brothers.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Be your will
Your own director; I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Why 'tis a match then.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Yet look well to your safeties; for myself,
Rhodes is mine object: dearest love, farewell;
This kiss seal my remembrance; mothers, let
Your only prayers assist me; for the rest,
Despair not till my downfall; go, away,
Reply not, if you love me; only Antipater,
sp.stage: Exe. all but Herod and Antip.
sp.l: Stay and attend me further. Princely youth,
Of all the hopes that do attend my life,
Thy greatness is my greatest; nor would I
Embark me in this desperate vessel thus,
Were't not to raise thy fortunes: but 'tis now
No time for courtship; only, I must leave
Two sad commandments with thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speak them sir,
Without exception, you cannot devise
What I'll not execute.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly said:
Thou seest the high priest Aristobulus,
And knowest how like a heavy weight he hangs,
Pressing our fortunes downward; if he live
Our lives have no assurance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis resolved,
He never sees tomorrow; soon at night,
When we do swim our wager, I'll so teach
His holiness to dive, that on the earth
He ne'er shall tread to hurt us.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Thou hast hit
The object that I looked at.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: (But shot wide
of goodness, and all good thoughts.)

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: This performed,
There yet remains another thing to do,
Which neerelier doth concern me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speak it sir;
Your pleasure is mine armour.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Briefly thus,
If through my fortune, or Augustus' wrath,
I perish in this journey; by that love,
Which nature, favour, or my best deserts
Can kindle in thy bosom; I conjure
And bind thee on the first intelligence,
By poison, sword, or any violent means,
To kill my wife Marriam; let no man
But Herod taste her sweetness; which performed,
My soul in death shall love thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Think 'tis done;
By heaven the hour which tells me of your death,
Is th'hour of her destruction; I have sworn,
And there's no fate can change me.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Be thyself,
Constant and unremoved; so farewell.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Two fiends like these were never spit from hell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Go Herod, happy King; nay Herod, go,
Unhappy, cause so happy; happy King,
Whilst thou'rt a King; unhappy when no King:
Hangs then mishap or hap upon a King, or no King?
Then Herod, be no King; Antipater be King:
And what's a King? A God: and what are gods, but Kings?
Jove, prince of gods, was petty King of paltry Crete;
Men subject are to Kings and gods; but of the twain,
Their gods than Kings commands, they rather disobey;
Kings greater then; nay, better than, than gods:
Then but a King or God, naught with Antipater;
And rather King than God; no god; a King, a King.
When I complain to echo but head-aching; it cries, a King:
When I, in mirth, am music making; it sounds, a King:
Each sight, when I am waking; presents a King:
When I my rest am taking; I see a King.
Last night I saw, or seemed to see; nay, sure I saw
A crown hang o'er my head; and through the crown a sword:
I saw, I sighed, I cried, oh when? O when?
Fall crown; yea fall with sword; fall both, so one may fall:
But why dream I of falling, that must rise;
Nay run, nay leap, nay fly unto a crown?
Giant's heap hills on hills, to scale high heaven;
Ay, heads on heads, to climb a kingdom's sky:
But o, I am a son; a sun, oh happy name;
A sun must shine alone, obscuring moon, and stars:
Ay, but I am a bastard; what of that?
Men base by birth, in worth are seldom base;
And nature's outcasts, still are fortune's darlings:
Bacchus, Apollo, Mercury; bastards, yet bravest gods:
Then, why not I a God, a demigod, or worthy?
You gods, you demigods, you worthies then assist me;
That, as our birth was like, our worth may bear like price:
If they refuse; come devils, and befriend me;
My breast lies open; come; come furies and possess it;
Hatch here some monstrous brood, worthy of you and me;
Which all posterities may know, but none believe;
Whereat the sun may not go back, as once it did,
At Atreus' tyranny; but fall and die for ever:
Whereat the heavens may quake, hell blush, and nature tremble;
And men (Half mad) may stand amazed. So, so, it works, it works;
My breast swells to a mountain; and I breed
A monster, passed description; to whose birth,
Come furies, and be midwives. Hark! O hark!

stage.p: Music: and, enter Aegisthus and Clytaemnestra dancing a coranto, which is broken off by the sound of trumpets: then, enter Agamemnon, and divers noblemen in triumph: Aegisthus whispers with Clytaemnestra, and delivers her a sleeveless shirt; then slips aside: Clytaemnestra embraces Agamemnon, he dismisses his train; she offers him the shirt, he offers to put it on, and being entangled, Aegisthus and she kills him; then departs, leaving at Antipater's feet two scrolls of paper.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So shall it be; shall it? no shalls; 'tis done, dispatched:
Who can resolve, can do; who can dispose, can better:
My way, seven single persons, and two houses cross;
Supported by a many headed beast:
oh, had they all one head, or all their heads one neck,
Or all their necks one body, which one blow might broach;
But had they Hydra's heads, Gerion's bodies; Hercules,
By making them away, would make his way to heaven:
But as an hunger-starved tiger, between two heifers,
Here yawns, there gapes, in doubt where first to fasten;
So doubt I where to set my paws, but care not where;
My father shall be first, that order be observed;
Whose death I wish, not work, lest piety be wanting;
Rome will I hope ease me of that disturbance:
Herod is come Augustus, friend to thy foe, and so thy foe;
Keep him Augustus, nay kill him Augustus, or Jove kill him and thee;
Pass he by land or sea, or hell, or under heaven:
Oh earth; food unto him, or none, or noisome give:
Oh sea; his ships or sink in sands, or drink in waves:
Oh heaven; or stop his breath, or lend contagious breath:
Oh hell; for kindness, call him in thy womb: in sum,
Gape earth, swell seas, fall heaven, hell swallow him:
But, let me see; what say my hellish counsellors?
Aegisthus woos, and wins, and wears a crown: a Queen
Receives with love (False love) the victor King; unnamed,
She cloaths him in her handiwork, a shirt,
Which had no head or arms to issue out;
Entangled thus they slew him: let me see,
What have they left? thus Clytaemnestra writes;
Per scelera semper sceleribus tutum est iter;
Fond is the stay of sin; sin safest way to sin;
Aegisthus leaves this axiom;
Nec regna scotium far, nec tedae sciunt;
None, or alone; Kings can endure no rivals;
I understand you well; and so will work;
Whetting against my father both his wife,
His sister and her husband; some by fear,
Some by belief, and some by jealousy:
Thus rise I on their heads, and with their hands
Rip up their natural bowels: 'tis decreed,
The plot is laid, parts must be played,
No time delayed.

div.stage: Enter lime the mason, handsaw the carpenter, and dirt the labourer.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: 'Tis a good handsome plot, and full of art;
But how like you my model for the timberwork?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.l: Pretty, pretty, if the seats be not too spacious.

sp.speaker: Dur.
sp.l: O, 'tis much the better, and fitter for the scribes and
Pharisies to sleep upon: but here comes the lord Joseph.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Well said my masters, and how mounteth the brave temple? may a man stand on the top of it and o'erlook the sun?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: The sun is very high sir; yet there is never an almanac-maker, but may lie on his back and behold Capricorn.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Tut, any foolish citizen may do that which hath his wife for his master: but stay; what's he?

div.stage: Enter Achitophel and disease, with a banner full of ruptures.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Come away disease, and hang up these my trophies,
Whilst I with gentle air, beat upon the ears of passengers.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: At hand sir, and here is your ensign; as for your drugs, there is not one of them but is able to send a man to God or the devil in an instant.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Come will you buy, for I have here
The rarest gums that ever were;
Gold is but dross and features die,
Else Aesculapius tells a lie:
But I,
Come will you buy,
Have medicines for that malady.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: O sir, it is one that undertakes to know more simples, then ever grew in paradise; 'tis rabbi Achitophel.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: What, the famous mountebank?

sp.speaker: Dur.
sp.l: The same sir.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Is there a lady in this place,
Would not be masked, but for her face;
oh do not blush, for here is that
Will make your pale cheeks plump and fat.
Then why
Should I thus cry,
And none a scruple of me buy.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Reverend Jew; I hear you're famed for many rarities;
As sculpture, painting, and the setting forth
Of many things that are inscrutable;
Besides you are a learned rare physician.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: I know as much as ere Sambashaw did,
That was old Adam's schoolmaster; for, look you sir:Sings.

lg.l: Here is a rare Mercurian pill,
An Anodine helps every ill;
The dissenterea, and the gout,
And cures the snivelling in the Snout.
The sick,
Or any crick,
Straight cures this diaphoretic.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: I shall have employment for you.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: The Jew is all your creature, and his skill
He'll willingly bestow upon your goodness.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: O sir, you shall not.

sp.speaker: Dis
sp.l: Yes sir, my master will willingly give you his skill;
Yet, with this memorandum, you must pay for his good will.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: I am no niggard, sir.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: Besides, my lord, there's never a pebble in Jordan, but my master is able to make the philosopher's stone of it.

sp.speaker: Dur.
sp.l: O wonderful! as how I pray you sir?

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.p: Why by extraction, solution, reverberation, coagulation, fixation, vivification, mortification, et multa alia.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Peace knave, I say, these pearls must not feed porkets.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: How, do you make swine of us? I tell you we are as errand Jews as yourself.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: No more, you're all for mine employment; you for stone,
You for painting, you for timberwork;
No man shall want his merit: go, away,
apply your labours, there's a largesse for you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O brave lord Joseph.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Come to me gallants you whose need,
The common surgeons cannot read;
Here is a balm will cure all sores,
Got in broils, or unwholesome whores.
Come away,
For why the day,
Is past, and here I cannot stay.

div.stage: Enter Alexandra and Marriam, Antipater and Salumith alofe.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: O cease my Marriam, tears can do no good;
This murder's passed example; to be drowned,
Drowned in a shallow murmur where the stones
Chid the faint water for not covering them.
O, 'twas a plot beyond the devil sure;
Man could not have that malice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam yes,
And 'twas some great one too that had his fist
Thrust in the blood of Aristobulus.

sp.speaker: Q. ale
sp.l: For which blood I'll have vengeance, and my tears
Shall never dry till it be perfitted.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Madam, forbear complaining; would this were
The worst of mischief's journey.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Know you worse?

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: I dare not speak my knowledge, though my heart
Leaps twixt my lips to utter mysteries.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: Note you that Salumith?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Yes. it hath pinched her on the petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, as you're noble, whatsoever you know
Of these mishaps, with freedom utter it.

sp.speaker: Q. Al.
sp.l: Utter it;
For heaven's sake utter it, noble, worthy lord.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Madam, I dare not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As you love virtue speak it; let my tears
Win so much from thy goodness; noble sir,
Soul of thy generation, thou honestest 'mongst men:
Oh speak it, speak it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Note you this courtship?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis sorcery.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Good sweet, unlock these counsels.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By all the bonds of chastity and truth,
It shall proceed no further.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: You have laid
Such strong commandments on me I must yield:
Hark, your ears.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: Are they not kissing madam?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Yes; may poison flow between them.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Antipater; he drown him!

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Nay, be still; you shall hear greater mischief.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Poison me, if he perish! O you gods,
What treason lurks in greatness; this hath made
Wounds in my heart, through which his love and name,
Is fled from me for ever!

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: 'Tis a fault
Which asks your deepest wisdom: come, let's in;
I'll tell you stranger storeys.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Yet I fear,
None that can draw more vengeance or despair.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: Awaken madam, they are vanished.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Not from mine outrage, that shall like a storm
Follow them and confound them; I will make
The world in blood, text down my cruelty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I cannot blame you, 'tis strange impudence.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: I'll be revenged; by all my hopes I will,
Highly and deeply; shallow fool, no more;
Still waters drown, the shallow do but roar.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll not be far behind, but help to send
All unto hell; 'tis for a crown I stand,
And crowns are oft the ruins of a land.

div.stage: Enter Augustus, Decius, Lucullus, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Thus have we quelled rebellion; thus (Like smoke)
Vanishes hence the name of Anthony:
Only some props remain yet; which I'll rend
Up by the roots and scatter: amongst which
Ungrateful Herod is a principal;
On whom I'll shower my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Gracious sir; the King of Juda, like a supplicant,
Desires access unto your majesty.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Who, Herod?

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Sir, the same.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: 'Tis a strange overdaring.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: An attempt wisdom would hardly run to.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Call him in;
he dares not come to brave us; Rome hath power
To shake a stronger building; and his fears
Are glasses of his danger: no man look
On Juda, but with hatred.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Mighty sir; to you, as him of whom I first received.
The crown of Juda, humbly I return it;
And thus arise. Know now (The great'st'mongst men)
'Tis not for life I plead, but honesty,
For virtue, valour, honour, prowess, grace,
And all good men's acquaintance: I confess,
I aided Anthony; if for that I fall,
A true friends tears shall be my funeral.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis a rare gratulation.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I'm afraid
New fear will alter it.

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Observe the emperor.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis true (Great sir) your sacred hand was first
Invested me in Juda; gave me that
I can forsake with comfort: keep it still;
Who from a crown is rid, is free from cares;
I prize the worth, less than two flaxen tears.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: This is a kind of braving.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Hear me forth;
And when you've heard; this, for extremity:
Since first the time I wore the sorrowful wreathe,
(For crowns and sorrows are incorporate,
And hang like links, one wreathed in another)
Since first the crown I wore, you knew my grieves;
But ne'er relieved me by person or by deputy;
No, not when Asia and the Afric strands
Joined both to overthrow me: only, than
The ever-praised (Now lost) mark Anthony
Thrust forth his hand and stayed me; he kept firm
My foot that then was sliding; ay, for this,
Sent him not aid, but rent long purchased.
O (Gracious sir) view mine obligements well,
And you shall see virtue did govern me.
Why, did his life yet lie within my hands,
Thus would I straddle o'er him as I stand;
Mine arms dissevered like two Rhodian props;
And ere I bent, my trunk should be the base
for his dread foes to build ambition on:
This would I do; and, if this be a crime,
It is so good an one, I scorn my breath:
Who lives the lives the longest still must end in death;
And so must I.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Thou art thine own judge Herod: call a slave,
A desperate slave; amongst all our prisoners,
Choose him that hath least mercy: you shall find,
Your friendship had a false ground.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Caesar, no; virtue was the foundation, and you may
Batter, but not o'erthrow it.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Well I'll try
The utmost of your fortitude: arm that slave;
And sirrah, kill that traitor; 'tis a work
That brings you home your freedom.

sp.speaker: 1. sla.
sp.l: Gracious sir, what is he I must murder?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: 'Tis a King.

sp.speaker: 1. sla.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Villain, why starest thou? Strike, I say, you slave.

sp.speaker: 1. Sl.
sp.l: Slave, I'll not strike; knowest thou or he, or he, or Caesar
What 'tis to be a murderer; nay, more,
The murderer of a King; nay, most of all,
To murder God himself; (For such are Kings:)
Oh you dull bloody Romans; see, in's eyes
Are thousands of armed armed angels; and each ray
A flame of lightning ready to devour
The hand that's lift 'gainst sacred majesty.
Caesar, I'm no italian; though thy slave,
I will not be thy devil; those are bred
Ith' shambles, let them butcher; fetch for this
Some from the Roman gallows; for they are
Hangmen that must perform it; and thou lookest
Like one: go, take the office, I'll not do it.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: The slave's afraid to strike him; timorous coward:
Call another.

sp.speaker: 1. sla.
sp.l: Timorous! Caesar, no:
Were I to scale a tower, or sack a town,
I'd do't; although the ruins fell like quarries on me:
Timorous! I ne'er feared mankind; Caesar, know,
Nor earth nor hell hath ought that can affright me:
I've buckled with proud Julius thine uncle, and was one
That, by expulsion, beat him from bright Albion:
And yet to kill a King, I'm timorous.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Let that slave have the weapon: sirrah, kill
That King, and have thy freedom: wilt thou do't?

sp.speaker: 2. sla.
sp.l: Yes, for my liberty,
As soon as you can speak it: shall I strike?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Stay, what's thy country?

sp.speaker: 2. sla.
sp.p: Rome, Rome; I was bred in one of those colleges where lechery and murder are pewmates: come, will you give the word?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Do not defer it Caesar,
I have made peace with my conscience long since.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Why then strike.
Yet villain hold; art not amazed to do't?

sp.speaker: 2. sla.
sp.l: Amazed, why?
To strike off these my shackles, such a blow
I would give to my father.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: But a worse
Shall fall upon thy carcase: bind that slave,
And throw him headlong down into the sea;
The earth's too much infected. — Herod, thus
Mine arms gives thee thy freedom: take thy crown;
Wear it with safety; and but be to me
Faithful; I'll love thee as did Anthony.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Caesar is royal; and, by this, hath bound
A faithful servant to him.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: For that wretch,
Give him his liberty; since thou'st served
Virtue, thou shalt serve Caesar; henceforth be
Commander o'er a legion: those that know
Goodness; by goodness ever greater grow.

sp.speaker: 1. sla.
sp.l: Caesar's a God in all things.

div.head: Act. 2. Scoena 1.
div.stage: Enter at one door Marriam and Alexandra; at another kiparim and Salumith, they meet and pass disdainfully.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: Lord how their poison swells them.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Sure they'll burst, if this strong colic hold them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mother, withdraw; the Greek begins to scold.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: And why to scold, proud madam?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, I want a tongue for your encounter.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: Yet this thing,
Of which thou art derived, ought to know
She owes me some obeisance; though she was
Mother to him that wore the crown, I am
Mother to him that wears it.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Tut, pride loves not to distinguish: goodly lord, not so much as how do you forsooth; (Every foolish citizens salutation;) nor hail to the sister of my lord the King, (Every court-coxcombs congee;) nor save you sweet lady, (Fools and physician's orisons)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How this shows.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: It shows that you are insolent.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Insolent: hug it sweetly, 'tis your own;
And every sin besides that's damnable:
Come, you're despised Grecians; so profane,
Ignoble and unholy, that our tribes
Are stained in your conjunctions; poor things, know,
Your titular King, in whom your glories dwell,
Is but a roy all murderer; yourselves,
And his proud bastard, bloody substitutes:
Oh, I could paint you bravely; for my grieves
Have all your perfect colours.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Come I could
Make you run dog-like back, and from the ground
Lick up the filth you uttered.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never sure;
She'll leave it where she found it.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Yes, and you
Leave virtue where you found it; hark you Queen,
You are unchast, and most incontinent.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Incontinent: with whom?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: His picture lies within you; pluck it out,
And let your false heart follow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is truth's part to suffer; so must I.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Vengeance upon such sufferance.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Come, you're a barbarous creature.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: Base Edomite.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Slanderous Grecian.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Old beldame.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Young cockatrice.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, I could tear thine eyes out.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Do but (This) that motion shall destroy thee.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Marry mew.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hold in the name of verve; here's a brawl
Able to inflame patience: beauteous Queen,
Divinest Alexandra; what can move
These storms in this calm weather.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Flattering sir,
You best can close up mischief.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If I may,
I'll lay my life a subject to your mercies;
Make me your footstools to appease your wraths;
My blood I'll make your sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: No more;
I that but now shed tears, now laugh: oh God!
To see so brave a masterpiece of villainy
By such a bastard issue be compacted:
Thou make atonement? Hence bastard, hence;
The dregs of lust, the foul disease of wine,
That wert begotten when sin was revelling:
Thou make atonement? No; go learn to drown
The lords elected people; here stands she
That looks to taste thy poison.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Miracles!
Wrest not my good thoughts (Madam) for I call
Just heaven to witness how I loved your son;
And would myself have died to ransom him;
But your misprision I impute to heat
And choleric spleen, which now misgoverns you.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: Nay, you should thank her for abusing you;
We are become her vassals.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Think not so.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Yes, and cry vengeance for it; wicked one,
There's wire whips in making, and I know
Furies will soundly lash you; you, and you;
Both are markted out to perish; faith you are.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: How now; what means this outrage? Peace for shame;
This talk fits stews and brothels: come, no more;
Mother, your judgement should be far more wise;
And madam, you should be more temperate:
A● princes hands, all injuries should look
Not for revenge but patience.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: Thou which art made of cowardice and fear;
dost thou confirm their actions?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis fit;
Lust still must flatter falsehood.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Ha; what's that? why wife —

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Call me not wife;
The sound of death hath far more music in it:
Wife? O, my fate! Wife unto such a lecher?

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Why Salumith.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: I'll be no Salumith of thine, there's your love;
She whom you foster in her insolences;
She's your Salumith: oh credulous women,
How easily are you gulled, with a seducing kiss!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now it works.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: A fair word makes the devil seem a saint;
But I'll be revenged, and in so strange a course
As never woman took. D'ye perpetrate my goodness?
There's your Salumith.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Admirable still.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: And there's th'old hen her mother,
A couple of seasoned dishes, fall too, fall too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay madam, you're too bitter.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: By heaven and happiness, I know not what this means;
Yet were the King not suddenly returned,
And craved our swift attendance; I would sift
And try this language strangely.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is the King returned?

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: He is, and safely.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: Then my hate, I'll give thee fire to work on.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: So will I; I'm armed with able mischief.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And my plots
Shall run as fast to aid and second you.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Ladies, shake hands with passion, and let's join
To meet the King with royal cheerfulness.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, not I;
Let them that love their horror seek it still:
Goodness I want, with him is all that's ill.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: You may report our speeches; say, our joy
Is, we have left no more he can destroy.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: This is a violent passion.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it rule;
Repentance needs must follow.

div.stage: Enter Herod, P. Alex. Y. Ari●. Pheroas, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Welcome, oh welcome to Jerusalem;
May Herod live for ever fortunate.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: We thank you: mother and sister, rise; let no knee bow
But to the gods of Greece; by whose support
We stand unshaked and unremoved: but ( methinks )
In this great universal rhapsody
Of comfort and amazement, I do miss
Two fair companions of my happiness:
Where is my lovely Marriam? what withdraws
Her mother Alexandra? Sure, my heart
Looked for their entertainment.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Gracious sir,
Th'unfortunate destruction of her son,
The high priest Aristobulus (Late drowned
Within t● river Rigill) so takes up
Their hearts with powerful sorrow, that their minds
Are born with nothing but calamity.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: That guest is soon removed; go, my sons,
Inform your grandmother and mother-queen,,
How much I long to see them.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: 'Tis a work
Worthy our duties.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Joseph, go, attend;
There's need of your assistance.

div.stage: Ex. P. Alex. Y. Ari. and jos.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Yes; and all I fear too weak to draw them:
Royal sir, you are abused in your credulity;
It is not grief but malice, bitter spleen,
An anger I may call treason, which keeps back
These two from noble duties: sir, they say
You do usurp, and are a murderer,
And teach all yours to murder; that you are
No lawful King of Israel; but a Greek
Descended basely; drawn from polluted blood:
Profane, unholy; nay, (Indeed) what not
That rancour can imagine? Sir, I fear
Your life is plotted on; a wrath like theirs,
So loud, so public, nay so impudent;
Is not without assistance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Bravely urged.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Good sister, think not so; a loss like theirs
Will make dumb patience mutiny; believe't,
it moves much in my own breast; as for plots,
Alas, what can they dream of?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Desperate things.
Things which may shake your foothold; for, I fear
The Queen is turned an Aspis, and will spread
Her fatal poison o'er you; if you dote,
The lethargy will kill you: sir, 'tis said,
Nay, 'twill be proved she is incontinent.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Incontinent! with whom?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: With him I blush to mention; Joseph sir,
Joseph my husband wrongs you.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Peace for shame;
Your jealousy doth fool you.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: Well, take heed
Affection do not blind you: 'tis a stain,
Almost the whole world finds out; and a truth,
Not hidden, but apparent; pray you sir,
Speak you what is reported.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis not fit,
Nor dare I credit rumor, chiefly when
It speaks of such great persons; yet 'tis true,
Many vild things are uttered; nay indeed
Some proved I wish were hidden: but alas,
Who knows not slander's ever impudent?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Do not give truth that title; for you know,
It will be proved by many witnesses.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Thou'rt jealous sister, and than such a fiend,
There is no worse companion: come, no more;
Should all the prophets, patriarchs, and priests
Lodged in the holy books of Israel
Come forth and tell this message, I would stand
Boldly and interpose them; for I know,
There is no truth to guard them; no nor faith.
O my divinest Marriam, how art thou
And thy great sweetness injured? Th'unblown rose,
The mines of crystal, nor the diamond,
Are half so chaste, so pure and innocent.
O poor forsaken virtue, how art thou
Torn down by thy despisers, and consumed
By th'envious flame of the malicious?
But I am come to guard thee, and restore
Thy goodness back with interest; for I vow
to hear naught but thy praises: here she comes;
sp.stage: Enter P. Alex. Y. Arist. Joseph, Marriam, and Alexandra.
sp.l: Welcome my dearest, sweetest, happiest,
All that my longings look for; thus, and thus,
Like a rich chain, my love shall hang about thee;
And make the whole world do thee reverence;
Nay weep not mother; come, I know your care,
And bear an equal burden: here, oh here
Is the true tomb of Aristobulus.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: You can dissemble royally; but that
Cannot cure mine impostume.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Say not so;
You must forget the work of accident.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Of accident? of plotted massacre;
Murder beyond example: but there's left
A hell to reckon with.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Good sweet, no more;
Let not your judgement wrong you to suspect
Mine innocence unjustly; for, I vow,
Never came death so near me; or did force
My tears in such abundance; but you know,
Earth must not question heaven: yet to show
My fair affection to your princely son;
Within an urn of gold, I'll lodge his bones;
And to his funeral rites, add such a pomp,
As shall amaze invention; and besides,
There's not an eye in all Jerusalem,
But shall drop sorrow for him.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Funerals are
But wretched satisfactions.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: Note this pride.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Yes, and her daughter's sullenness.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Why looks my lovely Marriam downward, and dejects
The glory of her bright eye? I had thought
My safe return (Which strikes a general joy
Through Juda and Jerusalem, and makes
Mount Zion so triumphant) had not had
The power to kill her comforts: lovely one;
How have I lost thy friendship; or, what fiend
Sends this divorce betwixt us?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your own dissimulation. Cruel sir;
You've dealt unjustly with me, and profaned
a temple held you sacred.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What, yourself?
O do not speak it; for to that blessed shrine
I have been so religious, that the world
Hath oft condemned me of idolatry:
And can you then accuse me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and call
Your own heart to be witness.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Let me then
Be struck with fearful thunder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, take heed;
Vengeance is quick in falling.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Let it come:
You call a love in question, that's as just
As equity or goodness; by that power —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, you will now be perjured; but I'll stay
That imputation from you: what became
Of your affection, when you bound that man;
If you miscarried in your work at Rome,
That he should see me poisoned? Start you now?
O, 'twas a venomed complot.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Sir, a word:
You're a faithless young man; and have lost
The great hope I had in you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By my life,
Hopes, and all fruitful wishes; I'm of this
As innocent as silence: if my lips
Ere opened to relate it; let me feel
Some sudden fatal judgement: gracious sir,
Search out this secret further, 'twill be found
There is more treason breeding.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I'm resolved.
Madam, you have accused me; and I stand
So strongly on mine own truth, that you must
Discover your informers: by that love
Once you did feign to bear me; by that faith
Which should link married couples; by the awe,
Duty and truth of women; or if these
Be cancelled with you fury; yet by that
Great power your King hath o'er you, and to shun
The scourge of torments, which I solemnly
Will try to the extremest; here I bind,
Nay, do command you, that unfeignedly
You tell me who informed you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You have laid
So great commandments on me, that I dare
In no wise disobey you. Sir, it was
lord Joseph that informed me.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Ha; Joseph!
O my abused confidence!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now it works.

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: The fire begins to kindle.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: But I'll bring
Fuel that shall inflame it.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Joseph? was't Joseph? then 'tis time to feel
My cold dull unbelieving.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: O pardon me;
It was my love, not malice.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: No, your lust,
And you shall buy it dear: call a guard.
Have I for this so often lost myself
Within the labyrinth of her wanton eyes;
And am I now repaid with treachery:
Cease on those wretched creatures; Salumith,
Stand forth, and what thy knowledge can approve
Against those traitors, speak it; now mine ear
Lies open to my safety.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Bravely speak,
You shall have strong supporters; now his ear
Is open, see you fill it.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Doubt me not.
Great sir, with confidence as full of truth,
As they are full of treason; I aver,
These, in your absence, have abused your bed,
With most incestuous foul adultery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: All that's like goodness shield me.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Woman, look up;
The vault of heaven is marble; this untruth
Will make it fall to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Let it come,
If I speak ought unjustly; all my words,
My blood and oath shall seal to.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: Good, let my love persuade thee; do not buzz
Such foul things in his ears; his majesty
Is too much moved already.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Good my lord,
Let me discharge my duty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, for that,
I dare not to withstand; yet, questionless,
The Queen is not so wicked. — go, put home;
You've all things to assist you: — sirrah Jew,
Forget not thy preferment.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Fear me not.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: How now, what tumult's that?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: O my dread lord,
grant me your gracious pardon; I must tell
A sad and heavy story; yet most true:
And yet 'gainst such a person, as I fear
Your ear will not receive it.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Speak; 'gainst whom?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Against the Queen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O sacred truth, but thee,
I have nor sword, nor armour.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Utter it.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Since your departure, to my hands she brought
This fatal viol; saying, Pheroas,
Thou art the King's cupbearer; by my love
I charge thee, when his majesty shall call
For wine, give him this potion; 'tis a draught
Shall crown thee with great fortunes: I desired
To know the nature; she, with solemn oaths,
Swore it was nothing but a wholesome drink,
Compounded with such art; that, tasting it,
You would dote of her beauty, and become
A very slave to her perfections:
I promised to perform it; yet my fear
Arguing with my judgement, made me try
The virtue on a spaniel; and I found
It was an odious poison.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Wonderful!

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: After this trial, I demanded then,
From whom her highness had it: she affirmed,
From the lord Joseph; but by stricter search,
I found this Jew was he compounded it.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: I do confess the Queen of Israel
Commanded me to try my utmost skill
In this most strong confection; said it was
To prove the force of simples: ay, her slave,
Durst not to disobey her; yet suspect
Made me reveal it to this nobleman.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: How answer you this treason?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Silently.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: That's a confession.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, as good be dumb,
As speak to ears are glued up; or a faith
That's armed against believing: but (Great sir)
If either of these open; then, believe't,
Was never wronged a greater innocence.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Malice hath wrought upon us, and o'erta'en
Our guiltless lives with vengeance: hell itself
Is not more false than these are; yet, I know,
Nothing can save us but a miracle.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The guilty ever plead thus; cursed chance,
To have my joys devour me: but, 'tis done;
Princes, your ears and counsels.

div.stage: Herod whispers with Ant. the princes and Pheroas.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Ha! is't so,
Hath mischief got the conquest; then 'tis time
To change my disposition, and deceive
Those which would else deceive me; in this kind,
It skills not whom we injure, whom we blind.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: Sir, of my life all this is counterfeit,
And this great devil enchants you; for these slaves,
They speak but what is taught them.

sp.speaker: Y. Arist.
sp.l: On my life,
Our royal mother's guiltless; do not let
Their hateful malice step between her life,
And your most gracious favour.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Princely youths,
Nature and love deceives you: wretched things,
What can you say to stay destruction?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That we're the Kings, and none are innocent,
Unless he please to think so.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Impudent!
Is that all thou canst utter? Have I lived
To see thee grow thus odious, to forsake
The chaste embracements of a royal bed,
For an incestuous lecher; to become
The people's scorn, the honest matron's curse,
The tribes disgrace, and Israel's obloquy;
Nay more, the whole world's wonder, and a stain
Ne'er to be washed off from Jerusalem?
O mine afflicted honour!

sp.speaker: Kip.
sp.l: Here's a change.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: A tempest never looked for.

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Pack for shame,
Run to thine own destruction: what, a whore?
A poisoning whore? A bawdy murderess?
Nay, more; a treacherous strumpet? O that heaven
Had made mine anger lightning, that it might
destroy thee in a moment.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Madam, stay;
Can your true goodness think me culpable?

sp.speaker: Q. Alex.
sp.l: Is it not proved apparent?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then be dumb,
Be dumb for ever Marriam; if you think
I can be guilty, who is innocent?
Madam, you are my mother; oh call up
Your worst imaginations, all the scapes
Both of mine infance, childhood or ripe years,
And if the smallest shadow in them all
Betoken such an error, curse me still,
Let me find death with horror; otherwise,
Silence and patience help me. Sir, 'tis fit
You plead your own cause; I am conquered.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: There's but one true judge over Israel,
And he knows I am guiltless.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis the plea
Of every guilty person: animis,
Convey those wicked creatures, with your guard,
Unto the marketplace, and there in sight
Of all the people, cause the hangman take
Their cursed head from their bodies.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: Stay, great sir,
Do not an act t'amaze all Israel;
Oh look with mercy's eyes upon the Queen;
The innocent Queen our mother; let not slaves
Blast her with false reproaches; be a god
And find out truth by miracle.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Y. Arist.
sp.l: No more? yes sure, if every word I speak
Should nail me to destruction: mighty sir,
Favour your own repentance, do not spill
The innocent blood unjustly; for th'account
Is heavy as damnation: to yourself,
And to your own, become a Daniel.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: O sacred sir, you must;
Upon my knees I beg compassion;
Compassion for my mother.

sp.speaker: Y. Arist.
sp.l: To this ground
We'll grow eternally; till you vouchsafe
to grant her mercy; or to give her cause
A larger course of trial.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Once again,
I charge you to forget her.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: How, forget
The chaste womb which did bear us; or the paps
Which gave us suck? Can there in nature be
A lethargy so frozen?

sp.speaker: Y. Arist.
sp.l: Nay, what's more;
Can we forget her holy stock, derived
From all the blessed patriarchs, in whom
You and ourselves are glorious? O, dread sir,
Have mercy on her goodness.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: Mercy, sir.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: How am I vexed with importunity;
Away to execution: if again
I do command 'tis fatal.

sp.speaker: Y. Arist.
sp.l: And if we
Endure it, let us perish; brother draw,
And let our good swords guard her: sir, you've broke
A link in nature's best chain; and her death,
Converts us to your mortal enemies.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What; am I braved by traitors? Villains, force
Way to the execution, or you perish.

sp.speaker: P. Alex.
sp.l: Mother, hold life but one hour and we'll rescue you.
sp.stage: The prince's force through the guard; Antipater draws and stands before Herod; all the rest convey away the prisoners; Alexandra wringing her hands.
sp.l: Did ever Kings own bowels thus become
The Typhon of sedition; or, can't be,
I could beget these serpents? If't be so
Under the Aetna of their damned pride,
I'll smother and consume them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, I know
Your wisdom such, as can discern what 'tis
At once to fear, to suffer, and to die,
By th'hand of stern ambition; which, ith' end,
Makes still her habitation like the place
Where poison grows, so naked and so bare
That dust disdains t'abide there.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Passing true;
But I'll root out that vengeance: yet again,
When I awake my memory, to look
Upon her sweetness, goodness, and conceive,
That no affair, no wisdom, or fond zeal,
which oft attainteth others, could touch her;
Oh then, methinks , I might at least have breathed,
Before I had condemned her; justice should
Ith' dark of these confusions, born a torch
Before truth and mine anger: but alas,
Folly and rashness led me; and I've lost
All my delight at one throw. Antipater,
Go, run, fly; oh, stay the execution.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Willingly. Yet please you first to think
Whether the act hurt not your majesty;
Kings, in these weighty causes, must not play
At fast and loose; their words are oracles;
And judgement should pursue them.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Good, no more; go stay the execution.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not on earth is there a man more willing;
Yet, when Kings condemn themselves of rashness,
Who can blame contempt to follow after?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Lord to see how time is lost with talking.

sp.speaker: Antip.
sp.l: I am gone.
Yet sir, believe't; the majesty which strikes
Against contempt shall ne'er recover it.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Yet again.

sp.speaker: Ant,
sp.l: Sir, I can vanish quickly; yet, behold,
Here's one can save my labour.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Speak my lord; where is my Queen?
O, where's my Marriam?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Sir, she is dead.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Dead? Be the world dead with her; for on earth
There's no life but her glory: yet declare
How died the woeful lady?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Like a saint.
Like did I say? O sir, so far beyond,
That never saint came near her precedent:
She did not go, as one that had been led
To take a violent parting; but as fate
Had in her own hands thrust her destiny,
Saying, or live or die: whilst she, that knew
The one and th'other's goodness, did agree
Only to die as th'act most excellent.
Her mother's bitter railings, all the cries
of the amazed people, moved not her;
No not one poor small twinkle of her eye:
But, with a constancy, that would outface
The brazen front of terror; she assends
Up to the fatal scaffold; and but once
Looked round about the people: then lifts up
Her snow-white hands to heaven;
Talks to it as if she had been in it: then falls down
Upon her humble knees; which, as they bent,
You might behold humility retire
Down to her heart; and left within her eyes
Nothing but sweetness flaming: whilst upon
And round about her, majesty did hang,
And cloth her as a garment: to be brief,
She took the stroke, not as a punishment;
But a reward; so saintlike hence she went.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Enough, too much; thou'st slain me Pheroas;
Oh, I have lost in her death more true joys,
Than heaven can give or, earth is worthy of:
I am a traitor to myself and love;
To nature, virtue, beauty, excellence;
I have destroyed the whole world; for but her,
It had no soul, nor moving; no delight,
No triumph, glory, or continuance:
I cannot live to lose her; call her back,
Or I shall die complaining.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is strange
Can the dead be awakened?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Easily sir,
My sighs shall breathe life in her; and my voice
Rouse her, as doth a trumpet; nay, more loved
Than either wind or thunder: canst thou think
That I can live without her; she, to whom
The whole world was a theater, where men
Sat viewing her good actions; she, that had
As much right unto paradise, as Kings
Have to their courts and kingdoms; she that lent
Mintage to others beauties; for, none are
Or good, or fair, but such as looked like her:
She, in whose body sweetly was contained
th'eastern spicery, the western treasure,
And all the world holds happy: may it be
That I can live and want her? or, could I
With one sad breath destroy her? she, that had
(In her own thoughts) read all that ere was writ,
To better, or instruct us: she, that knew
Heaven so well on earth; that, being there,
She finds no more than she did think on here;
And have I killed her? She, whose very dreams
Were more devout than our petitions;
Have I profaned that temple? Fall, oh fall
Down to the ground and perish; ne'er look up,
But when or blastings, mildews, lightnings,
Or poisonous sereneses strike thee. Herod, here,
Oh here, dig up thy grave with sorrow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fie, 'tis unfit greatness should yield to passion.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You're a fool;
He that not mourns for her, will never mourn;
But is worse than the devil. Marriam,
Oh Marriam; thou that through the spheres
(As through so many golden beads) hast run,
In one poor moment, to felicity;
Look down upon thy vassal, me thy slave,
And see how much I languish: let thine eye
Guild my complaints, and cheer my misery.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: O royal sir, take better comfort;
There was ne'er on earth a creature worth your sorrow.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Sir, you ●ie; deadly and falsely; for she doth deserve
The tears of men and angels: she, oh she,
Of whom the ancients prophesied, when first
They made all virtue's females; she, that was
The first and best fair copy, from whose lines
The world might draw perfection: she, not worth
The tears of all that's living? Dullness, go;
Pack from my sight for ever: oh, 'twas thou,
Thou that didst make me kill her: hence, avaunt;
By all that's good or holy; if, from hence
Thou ere presume to see me, or come near
the place of my abiding; 'tis thy death,
As certain as fate spoke it.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: O my lord.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Away; reply, and I will kill thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do not offend him further; vanish sir.

sp.speaker: Ani.
sp.l: To arms my lord, to arms: your princely sons,
Attended by the people, stand between
The town of Bethlem and Jerusalem;
Their ensigns spread, their bows bent, and their swords
Waving like wings of eagles: sir, they vow
Revenge for their mother's death.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: On whom?
On you, the city; but especially,
Upon the prince Antipater.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: No more,
They're angry surges, which with one poor blast,
I'll make fall to the centre; troubled thoughts,
Rest till this storm be over: happy man,
I'll make thee tread upon them; this day shall
Be thy coronation; but their funeral.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Twas a brave lesson that Aegisthus taught,
And Clytaemnestra writ religiously:
Sin safest way to sin; none or alone; both excellent,
Yet Herod lives unwronged and unremoved.
The sons of Oedipus, in life, nor after death,
Agreed but once; which was, t'imprison Oedipus;
An act of no small wonder: oh, but boys,
I'll mount a world above you; t'imprison, is
Still to have danger near me: tut, 'tis death,
Death that my aims do shoot at: I'll invent
What none shall alter: fie, 'tis nothing worth,
By worth, by birth, by choice, by chance to be a King;
But so to climb I choose, as all may fear and wonder;
Fear to attempt the like, and wonder how I wrought it;
Cursed be he (In this case) that craves his father's blessing;
My throne must be my father's monument;
My reign built on his ruin: but how? how? witless, how?
Ask how, and seek a crown? By poison; no, by sword;
sword; no, by subtlety: oh hell awake, awake;
And once for all instruct me.

stage.p: Music: and, enter Miscipsa, Jugurth, Adherball, Hiempsall, Miscipsa makes them join hands, and gives each a crown, and departs: then in mounting the tribunal, Hiempsall and Adherball sit close to keep out Jugurth, he divides them by force, Hiempsall offers to draw, and Jugurth stabs him; Adherball flies and comes in again with the Roman senators, they seem to reconcile them; and being departed, Jugurth stabs Adherball, and leaves at Antipater's feet a scroll.

sp.l: O resolute Jugurth; what affordest thou me?
Non mordent mortui; dead men do not bite:
True, noble bastard: Jugurth, in thy light
Thy brothers dwelled; oh Jugurth, so do mine:
Thou kild'st them Jugurth; Jugurth, so must I.
Thus sing we several descant on one plainsong, kill:
Four parts in one, the mean excluded quite:
The base sings deeply, kill; the counter-tenor, kill;
The tenor, kill, kill; the treble, kill, kill, kill:
In diapason kill is the unison, seven times redoubled;
And so oft must I kill: as, first the King,
(His wife is passed) two sons, two brothers, and a sister;
And think not but I can: can; nay, but I will:
I am no puny in these documents:
The tiger, tasting blood; finds it too sweet to leave it:
The hawk, once made to prey, takes all delight in preying;
The virgin, once deflowered, thinks pleasure to grow common;
And can I then stop in a middle way?
Close fountains, river's dry; pluck up the roots bows perish;
Banish the sun, the moon and star do vanish:
And, were it to obscure the world, and spoil
Both man and beast, nature, and every thing;
Yet would I do't; and why? I must, and will be King.
Kingly Antipater.

sp.speaker: Josephus
sp.l: Never grew pride more high, more desperate;
Nor ever could the arrogance of man
Find out a breast more large and spacious:
But fate and he must wrestle. Let me now
Entreat your worthy patience, to contain
Much in imagination; and, what words
Cannot have time to utter; let your eyes
Out of this dumb show, tell your memories.

stage.p: Enter at one door, with drums and colours, P. Alexander, and Y. Aristobulus, with their army; at another, Herod and Antipater, with their army: as they are ready to encounter, enter Augustus with his Romans between them; they all cast down their weapons at his feet and kneels; he raises Herod and sets him in his chair makes Alexander and Aristobulus kiss his feet; which done, they offer to assail Antipater, Herod steps between, Augustus reconciles them; then whispering with Herod, Augustus takes three garlands and crowns the three sons, Herod placing Antipater in the midst, and so all depart, Antipater using ambitious countenances.

sp.speaker: Josephus
sp.l: The sons of Marriam, having met the King,
Are ready for encounter; but are stayed
By th'awe of great Augustus, at whose feet
They cast their lives and weapons: he, with frowns
Chides the two angry princes; yet commands
The father to forgive them; peace is made:
Only against Antipater they bend
The fury of their courage; which the King
Withstands and reconciles them: all made sound;
Augustus gives them garlands, and installs
Them equal captains over Palestine:
But yet Antipater, by Herod's means,
Gets the precedence and priority:
How in that throng he justles; 'tis your eyes,
And not my tongue must censure: this we hope
Our scale is still ascending; and you'll ●nde
Better, and better; and the best behind.

div.head: Act. 3. Scoena. 1.
div.stage: Enter Salumith, and Lyme the mason.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: You must take my directions.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.l: Any thing your ladyship will have me.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Thou shalt inform his majesty; his sons hired thee, when his highness should approach to view the buildings, by seeming chance to throw some stone upon him, which might crush him to pieces. Do this and thou shalt gain by't.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.p: A halter, or some worse thing; for (Madam) the least stone that is employed about the temple, is 20. Cubits broad, and 8. thick, and that's able to break a man's neck without a halter.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: No matter.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.p: Nay, and it be no matter for breaking a neck (Though it be an ill joint to set) I'll venture a swearing for't.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Do, and live rich and happy; hold, there's gold.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.p: Nay, if I can get my living by swearing and forswearing; I'll never use other occupation.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Neighbour Lyme; news, news, news.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.l: What news, neighbour handsaw?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Marry sir, charity has got a new coat; for I saw a
Beadle just now whipping on statute-lace.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: And what's become of liberality?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Cry you mercy lady, faith she went like a bawd at a
Cart's tail, roaring up and down; but her purse was empty.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Th' art deceived her hand is ever open,
And to desert shees free; behold else.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: This is more of liberality, (As you call it) then I have found, since I began first to build the temple.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.l: Or I either.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: You shall have more,
We pour it on in showers; perform but my commandments.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Madam, by my handsaw and compass, I will do any thing; say, speak, swear, and forswear any thing your ladyship can invent or purchase.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Hark your ears.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Hum, ha; pretty, pretty; I'll play my part to tittle; neighbour, look to yours: nay, and I'll do it presently; for the King is now coming to the temple, and I came to call you neighbour; we'll do it there.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.l: What else; a man may be forsworn in any place,
City, court or country, has no difference.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: About it then; be constant wary and you're fortunate.

sp.speaker: Lym.
sp.p: Fear us not, if you want any more to be forsworn, give me your money, I'll press a dozen tradesman shall do it as well as any scribe in all Jerusalem.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I or publican either.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Away then.
Thus catch we hearts with gold; thus spiders can
Poison poor flies, and kill the innocent man.

div.stage: Enter Antipater with a letter, and Animis.

sp.speaker: Ani.
sp.l: Be swift as lightning; for the cause requires it:
Such paper-plots are invisible goblins;
Pinching them most, which do lest injury.
Y' are armed with full instructions.

sp.speaker: Ani.
sp.l: Sir, I am.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your letters are Chrysander's, and not mine.

sp.speaker: Ani.
sp.l: I know it well.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away then, outfly eagles; yet sir, hark;
Carry your countenance wisely, seem to be
A saint in thy delivery.

sp.speaker: Ani.
sp.l: Sir, your care
Makes you too curious, fear me not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Within there.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Did your excellence call?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I did; what, is your lesson got?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: My lord, unto a syllable; my tongue
Hath poison for your purpose, and I am
Confirmed in every circumstance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The time, (At night;) the place, (The bedchamber;)
The manner, (Armed;) the instruments, (Their swords.)

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Tut, this is needless; sir, my quality
Needs not a twice instruction.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nobly said; hold, there's gold.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: This is a good persuader; right or wrong,
Treasure will make the dumb man use his tongue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: True; 'tis the sick man's balm, the usurer's pledge,
And indeed all men's masters; go away,
The time's ripe for thy purpose; thus these slaves
Run post to hell for shadows; ha, Salumith:
Oh my best aunt and mistress; you're well met:
never were times so tickle; nor, I think,
Stood innocence in more danger: would my life
Were lost, to thrust fears from you.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Why, princely nephew, I've no cause to fear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis well you are so armed; indeed, a life
So good as yours, free, and religious,
Thinks not on fear, or ill men's actions:
Yet madam, still your state is slippery;
Believe it while these princes do survive,
And dream how you accused the mother-queen,
They still will practise 'gainst you.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Yes, and you;
The high-priests death, and Marriam's tragedy,
Will be objected 'gainst you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis confessed;
We're both marks of their vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Yet so far
Beyond them, I'll not fear them; here's my hand,
I've marked them for destruction: since our fates
Have equal danger; 'tis no reason but
They do enjoy like triumph; once again,
Believe it, they are sinking.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nobly said,
Mirror of women, angel, goddess, saint.

div.stage: Enter Tryphon the barber, with a case of instruments.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Peace, no more; here comes mine instrument.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What, this; the King's barber, your doting amorite?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: The same, observe him.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.l: O blessed comb; thou spotless ivory,
With which my mistress Salumith once deigned
To comb the curious felters of her hair,
And lay each thread in comely equipage;
Sleep here in peace for ever; let no hand
(But mine henceforth) be ever so audacious,
Or daring as to touch thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pitiful fool, go sleep, or thou'lt run mad else,

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.l: Sizers, sweet scissors; sharp, but gentle ones;
That once did cut the locks of Salumith;
Making them in humility hang down
On either side her cheeks, as 'twere to guard
The roses, that there flourish: oh, go rest,
Rest in this peaceful case; and let no hand
of mortal race profane you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sfoot, the slave
Will beggar himself with buying new instruments.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: O 'tis a piece of strange idolatry.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.l: Toothpick, dear toothpick; ear-pick, both of you
Have been her sweet companions; with the one
I've seen her pick her white teeth; with the other
Wriggle so finely wormlike in her ear;
That I have wished, with envy, (Pardon me)
I had been made of your condition:
But 'tis too great a blessing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What, to be made a toothpick?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Nay, you'll spoil all, if you interrupt him.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.l: Salumith, oh Salumith;
When first I saw thy golden locks to shine,
I broke my glass; needing no face, but thine:
When at those coral lips, I was a gazer;
Greedy of one sweet touch, I broke my razor:
When to thy cheeks, thou didst my poor eyes call;
Away flew scissors, basin, balls and all:
On y the crisping-irons I kept most dear;
To do thee service here and everywhere .

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Not everywhere good Triphon, some place still
Must be reserved for other purposes.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.l: Bright goddess.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Well proceed;
What, at a stand? has true love got the power,
To strike dumb such a nimble wit?
